Your task is to determine the stance of a given comment toward specified targets. 
Be precise, objective, and base your stance classification on clear textual evidence.

### Overview ### Stance classification is the task of determining the expressed or implied opinion, or stance, of a statement toward a certain, specified target. Your task is to analyze the news comment and determine its stances towards specific targets. ### Context ### Comment posted on date: 2014-08-10 00:23:37 # News comment title: 6 Dumb Things Dan Snyder Has Said About the Name of His Football Team # Oldest comment (from the thread): Good start, not saying the name. Id take it up a notch tho. From now on, use the term "bloody Indian scalp" instead of redskins. That will get some attention and maybe get some people thinking. # Most liked comment (from the thread): Nothing worse than a very lucky stupid fuck who doesn't have the decency to clamp his pie hole. Snyder must have looked at Trump (who is 20 years older) and thought..."what can I do to inherent that awesome legacy when he drops dead?". Considering that Trump has perfected the art of being a grossly idiotic misogynist, racist, anti-American bigot, Snyder has his work cut out for him. Digging in on a genocidal racist slur is a good start though. >>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<< Washington Powhatans? Any takers? Edit: Never mind, it should probably be the Washington Nacotchtank: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nacotchtank Washington Anacostia? Washington Piscataway? Washington Nanticoke? There are no shortage of Native and Native-derived names to choose from... >>> END COMMENT <<< ### Targets ### •Immigration / immigrants •Capitalism •Music •Israel •Politicians •Socialism / Communism •Elites •Sarah Palin •Ukraine •Climate change is (real | a problem) •Hobbies •Christians •Woke •Terrorism •Taxes are (good | fair) •Black people •Social media •Military •White people •Police •Food •Economy is good •Liberals •Democrats •Fossil fuels •Russia •Fascism / Nazism •Scientists •Conservatives •Barack Obama •Media •America / USA •Nancy Pelosi •Abortion •Christianity •Joe Biden •Social welfare •The government •Crime •Islam •Hillary Clinton •Jobs are (available | good) •Vegetarians / Vegans •Vaccines •Gay / LGTBQ+ •Diversity •Feminism •Journalists •Drugs •Progressives •Republicans (GOP) •Kamala Harris •Donald Trump •Muslims •Covid •Sport •Movies •Jews •Healthcare •China ### Task Description ### For each target, determine the stance in the comment: - If the stance is in favor of the target or agrees with the target, write FAVOR - If the stance is against the target or disagrees with the target, write AGAINST - If the stance is ambiguous, write NONE - If the comment is not related to the target, write NOT RELATED ### KEY CLAIM ### - Extract the fundamental assertion or belief that form the basis of the commenter's stance - The key claim should be expressed impersonalizing the user in the form of "I agree with the following: ". - If no stance is expressed (NOT RELATED, NONE) then leave the explanation field empty. ### Output Format: ### You must output only JSON format: { "results": [ { "target": "", "stance": "", "stance_type": "", "explanation": " if stance in FAVOR/AGAINST" }, // Repeat for each target ] } ONLY return the JSON object itself.

# News comment title:
GOP Candidate Asks Residents to Mail Him Their Pee

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
He isn't a scientist (and I am offended to have him associated with us) - that requires cognitive thinking (not just a degree).  This is guy is little more than a tin hat wearing nutjob, better suited for religion than theory.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
This is such a brilliant idea.  I'm considering mailing my feces to my GOP congressman for his consideration.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Problem #1 with this article:

The word "scientist" in the sentence "Robinson is a scientist" really should be in quotes.

# News comment title:
Why Ignoring Global Warming Is Like Driving Across a Rickety Bridge

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I shall defend our island planet, whatever the cost may be, I shall fight on the beaches, I shall fight on the landing grounds, I shall fight in the fields and in the streets, I shall fight in the hills; we shall never surrender to the fossil fuel foe. It is no use saying, 'We are doing our best.' You have got to succeed in doing what is necessary. This is our ultimate challenge, the stuff that epic history is made of. Don't stay home and watch it on the tele. Be there.  Be brave.  Share.

People's Climate March: NYC 9.21.14

http://peoplesclimate.org/

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
The "debate" format (two "sides" with equal time) favors liars.  That's because it's so much easier and quicker to tell an emotionally appealing lie than to explain what's false about it.  "A lie runs round the world while the truth is getting its boots on."  Especially when the lies have been repeated so many times that they can be invoked with a short phrase.  (E.g., "no warming since '98.")  Which is why the fossil fuel industries' public relations guys want a "debate" and PR-savvy scientists don't take the bait.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Very nice!  ...and I love that handle too.  You can't argue with 9.8 m/ss!  ...and I mean that literally, it's not actually possible to argue with the laws of physics.  Well played, friend. ;p

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Why Coal Is (Still) Worse Than Fracking and Cow Burps

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Uh oh. Someone at MJ didn't get the memo that fracking is bad. 

Seriously though. I'm really indifferent about my energy source, as long as my lights come on at night. I'm not particularly in love with coal fired plants because I think coal is awesome. And I'm not resistant to wind and solar because that's what dirty hippies like. 

The problem is, there is no cheap, reliable alternative to the energy structure we have now. I'd be more than happy to switch to solar or wind or whatever else as long as it was available. But it's not. And it seems to me that if the scientific community really cared about global warming, they'd quit spending millions trying to scare the hell out of everyone, and instead try to give us a viable alternative. 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Rockport, MO (a republican state I believe) claims it is the first city in the nation to be 100% dependent on wind energy.


It is spreading all over Iowa and MO. and somewhere west of Iowa because the enormous blades get carried west across Iowa nearly all year long.


Maybe we can't replace our energy from one source, maybe we need to find what works best in each area, while working on new ideas.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Probably another poor choice, but at least Diablo Canyon is on a bit of a bluff.

Edit:  Actually, you know what?  That's even dumber.  Those cliffs fall into the ocean all the time, and the thing is sited right at the edge.

Absolutely idiotic...

>>> END COMMENT <<<

Jimbo is correct that eliminating animals from one's diet is one of the most effective ways an individual has to lower her carbon footprint, even though animal agriculture itself is completely carbon-neutral. The reason why animal agriculture has a larger carbon footprint is because we use fossil fuels to run it, and it requires much more fossil fuel per calorie than plant agriculture. It's actually fairly important to understand the difference between the short and long carbon cycles, because disrupting the long carbon cycle is why we find ourselves in this mess and interrupting the short carbon cycle is one of the best ways to fix it. Treating any organic material anaerobically will lock down the carbon in it, whether that material be wood or cow pies. # News comment title:
Vanuatu's President: "Yes, Climate Change Is Contributing to This"

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
http://www.thegwpf.org/content/uploads/2015/03/Shortguide.pdf

I dare people to read this and decide which sounds more scientific to them in tone and approach, which side seems to rely more sensibly on evidence...and which side makes claims that are poorly substantiated by real evidence.


For the record: I am a luke-warmist. I believe human released CO2 adds to the greenhouse temperature and may impact climate. But I also believe most alarmist claims are outrageously unscientific and unsubstantiated by the data. The models have proved to have poor predictable value. And a witch hunt atmosphere has been created that is bad for science.

The evidence is that we have fewer storms now, far fewer, and there is no real evidence they are any stronger. Level 5 pacific cyclones are right on the average in terms of number per decade. Atlantic hurricanes are waaaaay down at historical lows. Tornadoes are also at historic lows. 

As with the Michael Brown shooting, I urge people to start looking at evidence more carefully, and try to understand the ideologically driven biases that impact reporting.

NOTE: watch the comments below for evidence of reality filtering. People will do anything to prevent any challenge to narratives they cherish. Rather than challenge themselves, they sink to sarcasm and excuses to avoid evidence they don't like. That's how filtering works.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Anything to avoid taking responsibility for their own actions.


That's how neofascist mental illness works.

Oops!  I accidentally gave you the wrong article.  That one's about mining landfill gas at Arlington.

The focus is on eliminating toxic waste from mixed trash, not sequestering carbon in biomass, but the outcome is precisely the same either way.


I actually wish they would stress the carbon-negative properties of the technology so more people would understand how valuable it is...

" "Ice extent is almost meaningless too." Not when it comes to sea level rise"
...so it is, actually, especially around Antarctica. What's happening there is that the melt from the land ice is freshening the water, which then spreads far out beyond the edge of the continent. This fresh water freezes at a much higher temperature than the rest of the water, so what happens is that as soon as the temperature dips a bit, the top layers of the water turn to ice and cover a broad area. If you look at the extent, it looks large, but it masks what's actually going on... which is exactly what dishonest propagandists for the fossil fuel industry try to do. A much better metric is volume or mass, and both of those are decreasing.

(Not because of the kaboom, that was me being a kid with bigger ideas than talent with hand tools.) Hydrogen gas is quite difficult to store long-term because it's molecules are so darned small they can leak through even a flawlessly-constructed container by slipping between the molecules that make up the container's walls. You can liquefy hydrogen, which makes that less of a problem, but liquid hydrogen (LH2) is *frickin' cold* even in absolute terms and the insulation needed to keep it that cold adds a lot of weight and bulk. NASA's doing a ton of work to make it easier to store LH2, because it's by far the most efficient rocket fuel we've discovered, but we've got a ways to go yet. That said, ground storage might not be too bad if you don't expect to keep a batch around for more than a few hours... but the smoking lamp around those tanks is *definitely* out. As for the article, it'll be interesting to see how the energetics prove out. I know the US Navy's been developing something similar for their nuclear-powered aircraft carrier fleet; making your own jet fuel at sea would save them a lot of logistical hassles, and after all if you have a spare nuclear power plant lying around un-or under-used it's tempting to put it to work on solving that. -- Steve >>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<
"hydrogen is a great fuel, except when it comes to storage. That's why recombining it with carbon is attractive, but that, of course, adds another layer of inefficiency to the process."
It is, and it does. This tech is making the news rounds today, and no one seems to be acknowledging the energy cost. Plants pull carbon from the air all day long, and they do it for free and using only the power of the sun. "Livestock produce methane gas which contributes to global warming."
This is common confusion! It's correct that methane is a powerful greenhouse gas. It's incorrect that biogenic methane contributes to global warming. All living things are carbon neutral. The carbon in us cycles from the air, to plants, to animals, and back to the air again. What's causing the problem is fossil carbon; carbon that's been buried underground for hundreds of millions of years being released into the atmosphere.
